I would say stick to Pareto principle. Remapping caps to control makes a huge impact on ergonomics. Changing layout to dvorak/colemak improves ergonomic, but requires some learning. Basic ergonomic keyboards won't give you a lot, custom ergonomic keyboards will take a lot of you time to get used to and to build/solder/adjust firmware and so on. In addition to that most ergonomic keyboards are not portable.

Non of those improvements will solve problems with neck/back/vessels.

I already invested some time to dvorak layout and a lot of time into custom keyboards.

In the future it will make sense to buy a laptop with ergonomic keyboard (when they appear). For now I would suggest to make a simple remap, maybe switch to better layout (~4 weeks, but can be beneficial in long term) and for sure learn how to organize your work and how to rest properly to reduce the usage of computer.

You can to change caps or whatever key to other key, it will be better, of course.

The basic ergonomic keyboard, as the not-stagged row and splitted keyboards, are very fine compared with classic keyboard and they help a lot to people with RSI problems.

The neck/back/vessels are questions related with your chair and enviroment, not related with keyboard.

For that questions, currently I use a expensive office ergonomic chair, with the necessary regulations.

My main layout is Dvorak, a layout that I had used since more than 5 years, that I recommend. Perhaps there are a any better layout, but I don't find yet the "best layout".

You can to obtain easily a prebuilt custom ergonomic keyboard, you don't need a engineering career for to buy one, the same way, you don't need to pay a software engineer for to make simple remap.

Also, the ergonomic keyboard are so portable as a classic keyboard, even you can obtain a specific bag for them if you want, but it's a irrelevant appreciation.

The laptop keyboard are the worst keyboard possible sadly, they are the opposite to ergonomy.

      make-backup-files nil
      auto-save-default nil
      auto-save-list-file-prefix nil)

I mostly experienced the problems with mutation in enterprise Java world and similar, but I don't see how this is specific to these environments. Every time people program with mutation by default I see lots of hard-to-find errors pop up. Humans are not good at constructing and keeping large state machines in their heads. Occasionally performance matters though
So I would argue that immutability is a huge time saver in the long run

And also I would think that referential transparency plays nicely with lisp's "everything is an expression" paradigm. How are you supposed to write nontrivial macros if you choose to construct not referentially transparent expressions?
The idea of variables not being variable confuses me. Are you supposed to create new variables instead of overwriting or modifying its value?

Yes and no. If you look at your code, probably most of it already does not use mutation, you just introduce local bindings to name some intermediate results and make things easier to read. Of course, any real world application is going to use mutation in one way or another (and Clojure does not prohibit this). The idea is to keep mutation only in places where it's unavoidable and leave the most code "pure".

So, for example, you don't need to mutate an array in-place to sort it. You can create a new one (if you don't have hard memory constraints). If you do this consitently, you don't have to care if you already sorted an array or not in any other part of your code.
I try to do things that way even in Java or other languages that don't make it easy to program like that. It helps making my brain sane
If you read Paul Graham's books he also argues in favor of functional programming (= programming with almost no mutation)

in java, they favor using getters and setters, and a setter generally modifies an existing variable attached to an object, so to preserve immutability, the entire object must be replaced with a new one
I do not represent the whole community but it's very safe to say that CL community does not find mutation problematic.

They do, but I don't :) You need to create a new object, but that doesn't mean you have to create all its field from scratch, you can just reference the old ones. I don't think this is easy in Java but in Kotlin it is (copy constructors for data classes. Data classes are a special kind of class with sane equality, hash code and value semantics. Might be called 'records' in other languages)

Just recently I had to implement some logic which was hard to do without mutation. Even though I tried hard to think about all the state transitions I still made a couple of confusing mistakes. That rarely happens to me when I write code without using mutation
Have you considered writing a library that would make it easier to write pure immutable code?
Do you mean for Common Lisp?
And which part of it do you consider hard?

text: For Java there is Lombok and Vavr and I believe a lot of other ones. I haven't used Vavr myself because I don't write Java for personal projects and couldn't persuade other programmers at my job on the benefits of immutability. So the least I could live with was
in Lombok. Also, I looked now there is @With annotation there that adds copy constructors just like Kotlin's data classes

messages.text: Generally, I don't think that trying to program in Java with immutability all the way is practical because the language and standard library works hard against you. But if you just keep the rule "try to make functions/methods always return the same answer for the same arguments" you will already make a huge step towards easier to read and modify code.

As another example of why mutability hurts, on that Java project I once debugged our system for 3 days straight to find the cause of NullPointerException. Turned out that a field was initialised after it was used (it was initialised in multiple places at different times for various cases, that's why it was hard to trace)

If whoever wrote it programmed with immutability in mind, he would initialise the object in correct state in one place and then hand off for processing later. This was plain data object with no acquired resources or other interesting initialisation logic

I would say there are 3 things that can be fun around software development.
1) High level design of software ("architecture" and algorithms)
2) Expressing your design as neatly and clearly as possible ("DSL" development)
3) Optimizing performance so that it runs fast
These are more or less technical things, there is also people's and product management but I am not sure how it is specific to software
Programming language is closely tied to 2) and often 3)

I would advise to start with Python first. Reads almost as pseudocode, has good libraries and documentation. So your projects would be easier to start with and get something done quickly (project setup is sometimes not super straightforward with Python though). Then when you feel comfortable you can start exploring what other languages have to offer (it's usually advanced features that the majority of software developers either do not understand how to use or did not hear about). Also, I would advise to get your opinion on OOP vs functional programming and static vs dynamic typing. Then you'll probably be choosing between 2-3 languages that best suit you.

messages.text:
i wrote this to be able to write up curried functions like
(defcurry d/dx (dx f x)
  (/ (- (funcall f (+ x dx))
        (funcall f x)) 
     dx))

So if you want a derivative at a given precision you then use another macro
(uncurry (d/dx 1e-3) as derivative-approximate)
